questions.text: Who wrote 'The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'?
questions.explanation: Robert Louis Stevenson.

questions.text: Sitting Bull was the leader of which tribe of North American Indians?
questions.explanation: Sioux.

questions.text: A horologist is an expert maker of ....?
questions.explanation: Timepieces (clocks and watches).

questions.text: What is a Rolex Oyster?
questions.explanation:
Waterproof wrist watch.

	Its tightly-sealed, solidly waterproof design was tested by swimmer Mercedes Gleitz who crossed from France to England on 7 Oct. 1927 in 15 hours 15 minutes.

questions.text: In what sport is the term 'slam dunk' used?
questions.explanation:
Basketball.

	It is a basketball term describing a vigorous overhand shot.

questions.text: Of the following countries, how many are the correct official language: Austria - Austrian, Bulgaria - Bulgarian, Hungary - Hungarian, Norway - Norwegian?
questions.explanation:
3.

	German is the official language of Austria.

questions.text: What were the first names of the Wright brothers who made the world's first piloted flight in a power-driven, heavier than air machine?
questions.explanation: Wilbur and Orville.

questions.text: In motorcar International identification letters: 'E' is Spain, 'D' is Germany, 'C' is Cuba, 'B' is Belgium. Which country is represented by 'A'?
questions.explanation:
Austria.

	Andorra (AND), Argentina (RA) and Australia (AUS).

questions.text: What international paper size is 210 by 297 mm. or 8.27 by 11.69 inches?
questions.explanation:
A4.

	The same size paper that is in your printer at present. 'A3' paper is double the size of 'A4'.

questions.text: XCIX is the Roman numerals for which number?
Which animal has an offspring called a cub and its collective group is called a sleuth?
questions.explanation: Bear.

questions.text: Which two planets' atmospheres are mainly carbon dioxide?
questions.explanation:
Venus and Mars.

	The atmospheres of both Venus and Mars are approximately 95 percent carbon dioxide.

questions.text: Name the powerful current caused by conflicting tides around the Shetland and Orkney Islands?
questions.explanation: Roost.

questions.text: Which Marilyn Monroe film shares the same film title as a Marx Brothers film?
questions.explanation:
Monkey Business.

	1952 Marilyn Monroe film and 1931 Marx Brothers film.

questions.text: Name the rich sauce of egg yolks, butter and lemon juice usually served with fish?
questions.explanation:
Hollandaise.

	Mayonnaise is a thick creamy sauce made from egg yolks, oil and vinegar eaten with salads.

questions.text: Herman Melville's classic novel, Moby Dick, tells the story of Captain Ahab and his hunt for what type of whale that tore off his leg?
questions.explanation: Great white sperm whale.

questions.text: In Australian Aborigine mythology, name the golden age when the first ancestors were created?
questions.explanation:
Dream time.

	Also called alcheringa or alchera which from the native Australian language literally means dream time.

questions.text: The foxtrot is a famous dance alternating long and short steps in quadruple time. It was named in 1914 in New York City after music writer...
questions.explanation: Harry Fox.

questions.text: How many of the following statements about Benjamin Franklin are true: He developed the lightning conductor, bought and ran the Pennsylvania Gazette newspaper (1730's), invented bifocal spectacles (1784), vigorous anti-slavery campaigner.
questions.explanation: All are true.

questions.text: Predicting the future by examining the pattern made by loose tealeaves left at the bottom of a cup is called what?
questions.explanation:
Foliomancy.

	Cheiromancy is predicting the future by palm reading, cartomancy is by the dealing of playing cards and oomancy is by breaking eggs and observing the shapes produced.

questions.text: How many players are there on a side in men's lacrosse?
questions.explanation:
10.

	In women's lacrosse the field is larger and is played with twelve players per side.

questions.text: Which metal acquired its name from the Swedish name for 'heavy stone'?
questions.explanation:
Tungsten.

	From Swedish 'tung sten' (heavy stone) with chemical symbol 'W' for wolfram. Mercury is a silvery metallic liquid.

questions.text: On this country's flag, the orange stripe represents the Sahara in the north and the green stripe, the grasslands in the south. Between them, the white stripe represents the River Niger, with an orange circle for the sun?
questions.explanation: Niger.

questions.text: The 18th century French scientist Antoine Lavoisier developed the system for naming chemical compounds that is still in use today. How did he die?
questions.explanation:
Guillotined.

	Guillotined during the French Revolution as he had been a tax collector for the pre-Revolutionary regime.

questions.text: Where was Miguel de Cervantes when he began writing his classic novel 'Don Quixote'?
questions.explanation:
In prison.

	He was imprisoned in Spain in 1597. Hope you enjoyed the quiz.
